compartmental_metamodel.description: EpiMDE Compartmental Metamodel - Unified framework for epidemiological models, classical traffic networks, and Traffic Reaction Model (TRM) with parametric (symbolic) modeling support

changelog.3.1: Added Traffic Reaction Model (TRM) support with flux decomposition, dual variable tracking, and kinetic interpretation. New decomposition types: TRM_MAK, TRM_GODUNOV, TRM_CAPACITATED. Extended TRM with capacity drop factors. Fully backward compatible.
changelog.3.0: Added traffic network modeling with supply-demand dynamics, PP/FIFO junction rules, and triangular fundamental diagram support. Fully backward compatible with disease models.
changelog.2.0: Added comprehensive parameter system for symbolic/parametric modeling with Unicode support

parameters.description: Named parameters for symbolic/parametric modeling. Enables separation of model structure from parameter values.

name.description: Parameter identifier. Supports Unicode including Greek letters (α, β, γ, δ, μ, ρ, θ, λ) and subscripts (ₕ, ᵥ, ₁, ₂)

type.description: Parameter type: CONSTANT (default), VARIABLE, or EXPRESSION

expression.description: For CONSTANT/VARIABLE: numeric value. For EXPRESSION: mathematical formula referencing other parameters/compartments

examples: Natural mortality rate of human population

unit.description: Physical unit of measurement. Supports Unicode symbols.

CONSTANT.description: Fixed value with a name, used for model parameters that don't change during simulation
CONSTANT.example: <parameters name="μₕ" expression="0.001384" description="Natural mortality rate" unit="1/time"/>

VARIABLE.description: Placeholder for values provided at simulation time, such as environmental conditions or intervention levels

EXPRESSION.description: Computed value defined as a mathematical expression referencing other parameters and/or compartments
EXPRESSION.example: <parameters name="β₂a(T)" type="EXPRESSION" expression="β₂ * a(T)" description="Combined contact rate" unit="1/time"/>

constraints.junctionRule: Optional. For traffic models use PPFIFO. For disease models use NONE (default).

SecondaryName.description: Additional descriptor for stratification or link type

population.description: Initial population count (disease models) or initial density (traffic models)

junctionRule.description: Junction rule type for traffic models. NONE for disease models (default), PPFIFO for traffic networks.

supplyFunction.description: Flow network supply and demand functions based on capacity constraints. Supports classical traffic models (Coogan & Arcak 2015) and Traffic Reaction Model (TRM) with kinetic decompositions (Pereira et al. 2024). Generalizable to traffic networks, queue systems, pipeline networks, etc. Only present for flow-constrained models. Disease models do not have this element.

isSourceNode.description: Boolean indicating if this is a source/entry node with external input (true) or constrained internal node (false)
examples: Onramps in traffic, generators in systems, entry queues in networks

maxDensity.description: Maximum density/capacity - saturation point (constrained nodes only)
maxDensity.traffic_example: ρ^jam - vehicles per length when stopped

criticalDensity.description: Critical density/threshold - point of maximum throughput (constrained nodes only)

maxThroughput.description: Maximum throughput/capacity - max flow rate (constrained nodes only)

maxDemand.description: Maximum demand/output rate - upper bound on outflow (source nodes only)
maxDemand.traffic_example: Φ^max - max vehicles per hour from onramp

omega.description: Reaction rate constant ω for TRM_MAK (Mass Action Kinetic) decomposition. Used in flux g(ρ,ν) = ωρν where ν = ρ_max - ρ (TRM models only)

capacityDropFactor.description: Time-varying capacity drop factor C_i(t) for Extended TRM models. Enables modeling of changing traffic conditions (incidents, construction, weather). Value in range (0, 1] where 1 = normal capacity (TRM models only)

enableDualVariable.description: Boolean flag to enable dual variable tracking: ρ (vehicle density) and ν (free space density) where ν = ρ_max - ρ. Enables kinetic/compartmental interpretation of TRM (TRM models only)
enableDualVariable.note: When true, simulation tracks both occupied space N_i and free space S_i

examples.trm_mak_node: <supplyFunction type="TRM_MAK" isSourceNode="false" maxDensity="360" criticalDensity="90" maxThroughput="3000" omega="0.001" enableDualVariable="true"/>
examples.trm_godunov_node: <supplyFunction type="TRM_GODUNOV" isSourceNode="false" maxDensity="360" criticalDensity="90" maxThroughput="3000" enableDualVariable="true"/>
examples.extended_trm_node: <supplyFunction type="TRM_CAPACITATED" isSourceNode="false" maxDensity="360" criticalDensity="90" maxThroughput="3000" capacityDropFactor="0.8" enableDualVariable="true"/>

parametric.description: Reference a Parameter by index. Parameter takes precedence over numeric rate.

rate.description: Numeric rate value. For parametric models, set to 0.0 and use rateParameter instead.

rateParameter.description: Reference to a Parameter defining this flow's rate. Format: '//@parameters.X' where X is 0-based index.

parametric.description: Reference a Parameter by index. Parameter takes precedence over numeric contactRate.

contactRate.description: Numeric contact/transmission rate. For parametric models, set to 0.0 and use contactRateParameter instead.

contactRateParameter.description: Reference to a Parameter defining this flow's contact rate. Format: '//@parameters.X' where X is 0-based index.

contactCompartment.description: Reference to compartment influencing transmission (usually Infectious or Infected Mosquitoes)
contactCompartment.constraint: Must reference existing compartment using format '//@compartments.X'

attributes.rate: Numeric rate value for this stratum
attributes.rateParameter: Reference to Parameter for this stratum's rate
attributes.multiplier: Numeric multiplier applied to base rate (defaults to 1.0)

constraints.multiplier: Must be float/decimal value, defaults to 1.0

attributes.rateParameter: Reference to Parameter for birth rate. Format: '//@parameters.X'
Reference to Parameter for death rate. Format: '//@parameters.X'

constraints.values: Array of string values representing the group stratification levels

RateFlow.description: Rate-based transition independent of other compartment populations. Supports both numeric rates and parameter references.
RateFlow.use_numeric_when: Model has hardcoded rates (legacy models, simple demonstrations)
RateFlow.use_parametric_when: Model needs symbolic equations, parameter reuse, or matching published papers

ContactFlow.description: Contact-based transmission dependent on another compartment's population. Models frequency-dependent or density-dependent transmission. Supports both numeric rates and parameter references.
examples: Susceptible Humans → Exposed Humans (contact with Infectious Mosquitoes)
Susceptible Mosquitoes → Exposed Mosquitoes (contact with Infectious Humans)

parameters.contactCompartment: Source compartment for transmission (usually Infectious or vector compartment)

ContactFlow.use_numeric_when: Simple models with constant transmission rates
ContactFlow.use_parametric_when: Complex transmission (temperature-dependent, combined rates, symbolic equations)

stratification.description: Age-based or demographic stratification using Groups and Products
stratification.stratum_specific_rates: Different rates can be specified for each stratum within a flow. Supports both numeric and parametric approaches.

validation_rules.Inflow: Use BirthSource elements for population inflows. The inflow to a compartment which doesn't have a source (like recruitment or birth) should use birthSources rather than regular flows
validation_rules.Outflow: Use DeathSink elements for population outflows. Natural death and other population losses should use deathSinks rather than flows to non-existent compartments
validation_rules.compartment_uniqueness: Each (PrimaryName, SecondaryName) pair must be unique
validation_rules.index_consistency: Target indices must reference existing compartments using format '//@compartments.X'
validation_rules.reference_consistency: Product references must use format '//@products.X', Group references must use format '//@groups.X', Parameter references must use format '//@parameters.X'
validation_rules.rate_format_numeric: For numeric modeling: All rates must be numeric values (avoid symbols). Compute a final float numeric value, not an equation.
validation_rules.rate_format_parametric: For parametric modeling: Set numeric rates to 0.0 and use rateParameter/contactRateParameter references instead.
validation_rules.parameter_uniqueness: Parameter names must be unique within a model
validation_rules.parameter_references: All parameter references must point to existing parameters using 0-based indexing
validation_rules.flow_type_consistency: Use xsi:type="seir:RateFlow" for progression flows, xsi:type="seir:ContactFlow" for transmission flows
validation_rules.stratification_consistency: Compartments with product attribute should have stratumSpecificRates in their flows where applicable
validation_rules.terminal_compartments: Terminal compartments (like Deaths, Recovered) typically have no outgoing flows (exception: loss of immunity)
validation_rules.contact_flow_validation: ContactFlow must specify contactCompartment (usually an Infectious compartment) and either contactRate or contactRateParameter
validation_rules.stratum_validation: stratumSpecificRates stratum values must match the values defined in the referenced Group
validation_rules.population_balance: BirthSources and DeathSinks help maintain population balance in the model
validation_rules.description: Even though description is optional, it would be very helpful if each flow has a brief description explaining the purpose of this flow.
validation_rules.unicode_support: Parameter names support Unicode including Greek letters (α, β, γ, δ, μ, ρ, θ, λ) and subscripts (ₕ, ᵥ, ₁, ₂)

flow_network_validation.supply_function_required: Flow-constrained compartments must have a supplyFunction element
flow_network_validation.junction_rule_required: Flow network compartments must set junctionRule="PPFIFO" or "CUSTOM"
flow_network_validation.source_node_attributes: Source nodes (isSourceNode=true) must specify maxDemand but not maxDensity/criticalDensity/maxThroughput
flow_network_validation.constrained_node_attributes: Constrained nodes (isSourceNode=false) must specify maxDensity, criticalDensity, maxThroughput but not maxDemand
flow_network_validation.split_ratios: Outgoing flows from network compartments should use RateFlow with parameters representing split ratios/routing coefficients
flow_network_validation.source_node_input: Source nodes should have a BirthSource with rateParameter for external input/demand
flow_network_validation.consistency: All compartments in a model should be either all flow-network (with supplyFunction) or all disease (without supplyFunction)

trm_validation.trm_type_validation: TRM compartments must use type="TRM_MAK", "TRM_GODUNOV", or "TRM_CAPACITATED"
trm_validation.trm_mak_omega: TRM_MAK type requires omega attribute to be specified (reaction rate constant ω)
trm_validation.capacity_drop_range: capacityDropFactor must be in range (0, 1]: 0 < C_i(t) ≤ 1
trm_validation.dual_variable_flag: enableDualVariable="true" recommended for TRM models to track both ρ and ν = ρ_max - ρ
trm_validation.trm_base_attributes: All TRM compartments must specify maxDensity (ρ_max), criticalDensity (ρ_crit), and maxThroughput (Φ_max)
trm_validation.extended_trm_capacity: Extended TRM models with capacityDropFactor should use values < 1.0 to model reduced capacity scenarios
trm_validation.trm_compatibility: TRM models are compatible with classical traffic models - can mix TRIANGULAR and TRM types in same network
trm_validation.godunov_equivalence: TRM_GODUNOV with proper configuration is equivalent to Cell Transmission Model (CTM)

traffic_networks.description: NEW in Version 3.0: Traffic network modeling with supply-demand dynamics and PP/FIFO junction rules
features: Supply and demand functions for road links (triangular fundamental diagram)
PP/FIFO (Proportional Priority, First-In-First-Out) junction rules
Onramps as unbounded queues with max demand
Ordinary links with capacity constraints
Non-cooperative dynamics for traffic optimization
Backward compatible with disease models

SupplyFunction.description: Defines traffic flow characteristics based on vehicle density

source_nodes.description: Entry points with unbounded storage (e.g., onramps in traffic, generators in systems)

constrained_nodes.description: Internal nodes with capacity constraints (e.g., road segments in traffic, pipes in flow networks)
constrained_nodes.demand: Φ^out(ρ) = min((maxThroughput/criticalDensity)*ρ, maxThroughput) for ρ ≤ criticalDensity; maxThroughput for ρ > criticalDensity
constrained_nodes.supply: Φ^in(ρ) = maxThroughput for ρ ≤ criticalDensity; (maxThroughput/(maxDensity-criticalDensity))*(maxDensity-ρ) for ρ > criticalDensity

JunctionRule.description: Specifies how flows are computed at network junctions

ppfifo_rule.description: α_v(ρ) = max{α ∈ [0,1] : α Σ_{j∈incoming} β_{jk} Φ^out_j(ρ_j) ≤ Φ^in_k(ρ_k) ∀k∈outgoing}
ppfifo_rule.computation: At each time step, compute α that satisfies downstream supply constraints
ppfifo_rule.output_flow: f^out_l(ρ) = α_v(ρ) * Φ^out_l(ρ_l) for all incoming links

traffic_models.note: f^out and f^in computed via PP/FIFO rule with supply-demand constraints

backward_compatibility.description: Traffic features are fully optional - disease models work unchanged
backward_compatibility.traffic_models: Add supplyFunction element and set junctionRule=PPFIFO
backward_compatibility.detection: Presence of supplyFunction element indicates traffic model

source_node_traffic.description: Source node (onramp) with max demand 3000 vehicles/hour
source_node_traffic.xml:
<compartments PrimaryName="Onramp1" population="0" junctionRule="PPFIFO">
  <supplyFunction type="TRIANGULAR" isSourceNode="true" maxDemand="3000"/>
  <outgoingFlows xsi:type="seir:RateFlow" rateParameter="//@parameters.0" target="//@compartments.1"/>
</compartments>

constrained_node_traffic.description: Constrained node (road link) with capacity constraints
constrained_node_traffic.xml:
<compartments PrimaryName="Link2" population="37.5" junctionRule="PPFIFO">
  <supplyFunction type="TRIANGULAR" isSourceNode="false" maxDensity="360" criticalDensity="90" maxThroughput="3000"/>
  <outgoingFlows xsi:type="seir:RateFlow" rateParameter="//@parameters.1" target="//@compartments.2"/>
</compartments>

disease_compartment.description: Disease compartment (unchanged - no flow network features)
disease_compartment.xml:
<compartments PrimaryName="Susceptible" population="1000">
  <outgoingFlows xsi:type="seir:ContactFlow" contactRateParameter="//@parameters.0" contactCompartment="//@compartments.1" target="//@compartments.1"/>
</compartments>

references: Coogan, S., & Arcak, M. (2015). A Compartmental Model for Traffic Networks and its Dynamical Behavior. IEEE Trans. Automatic Control, 60(10), 2698-2703.
Daganzo, C. F. (1994). The Cell Transmission Model: A Dynamic Representation of Highway Traffic. Transportation Research Part B, 28(4), 269-287.

traffic_reaction_model.description: NEW in Version 3.1: Traffic Reaction Model (TRM) - A kinetic compartmental approach to road traffic modeling with flux decomposition and dual variable tracking (Pereira et al. 2024)
features: Flux decomposition: f(ρ) = g(ρ, ρ_max - ρ) using dual variables
Dual variable tracking: ρ (vehicle density) and ν (free space density)
Kinetic interpretation: traffic as chemical reactions between compartments
Multiple decomposition types: MAK, Godunov, Capacitated
TRM-CTM equivalence: TRM is equivalent to Cell Transmission Model
Extended TRM: Time-varying capacity drop factors C_i(t)
Network TRM: Multi-lane intersections with incoming/outgoing flows
Fully backward compatible with classical traffic models

mathematical_foundation.flux_decomposition: f(ρ) = g(ρ, ν) where ν = ρ_max - ρ

TRM_MAK.name: Mass Action Kinetic decomposition
use_cases: Studying kinetic interpretation of traffic flow

TRM_GODUNOV.name: Godunov decomposition
characteristics: Compatible with CTM and Coogan & Arcak 2015
TRM_GODUNOV.note: TRM with Godunov decomposition is equivalent to CTM with specific input capacity

TRM_CAPACITATED.name: Capacitated decomposition
characteristics: Multiplicative coupling of demand and supply

dual_variable_interpretation.description: TRM interprets road segments as compartments with two species
dual_variable_interpretation.vehicle_density: ρ_i(t) = N_i(t)/Δx (occupied space per unit length)
dual_variable_interpretation.conservation: N_i + S_i = ρ_max * Δx (constant total capacity)
benefits: Enables application of reaction network theory
Lyapunov stability analysis using entropy functions
Connection to chemical reaction network theory

extended_trm.description: Extended TRM with time-varying capacity drop factors
extended_trm.modified_flux: g(ρ, ν) with ν = C_i(t) * ρ_max - ρ

network_trm.description: Extension to road networks with junctions
network_trm.compatibility: Works with existing PP/FIFO junction rules
network_trm.routing: Uses RateFlow with split ratio parameters

trm_ctm_equivalence.description: TRM with Godunov decomposition is equivalent to CTM
trm_ctm_equivalence.key_insight: TRM provides kinetic interpretation of CTM
trm_ctm_equivalence.practical_impact: TRM and CTM produce identical simulation results when properly configured

stability_analysis.description: TRM inherits stability properties from reaction network theory
stability_analysis.persistence: All trajectories remain in interior of state space

compartments.description: Road segments as compartments with supplyFunction element

examples: ω: reaction rate constant for MAK

flows.description: Use RateFlow for routing between segments
flows.junction_rule: Set junctionRule="PPFIFO" or "NONE" for exit cells

trm_mak_cell.xml:
<compartments PrimaryName="Cell1" population="50" junctionRule="PPFIFO">
  <supplyFunction type="TRM_MAK" isSourceNode="false" maxDensity="360" criticalDensity="90" maxThroughput="3000" omega="0.001" enableDualVariable="true"/>
  <outgoingFlows xsi:type="seir:RateFlow" rateParameter="//@parameters.0" target="//@compartments.1"/>
</compartments>

trm_godunov_cell.xml:
<compartments PrimaryName="Cell2" population="75" junctionRule="PPFIFO">
  <supplyFunction type="TRM_GODUNOV" isSourceNode="false" maxDensity="360" criticalDensity="90" maxThroughput="3000" enableDualVariable="true"/>
  <outgoingFlows xsi:type="seir:RateFlow" rateParameter="//@parameters.1" target="//@compartments.2"/>
</compartments>

extended_trm_cell.description: Extended TRM with capacity drop (incident zone)
extended_trm_cell.xml:
<compartments PrimaryName="IncidentZone" population="120" junctionRule="PPFIFO">
  <supplyFunction type="TRM_CAPACITATED" isSourceNode="false" maxDensity="360" criticalDensity="90" maxThroughput="3000" capacityDropFactor="0.6" enableDualVariable="true"/>
  <outgoingFlows xsi:type="seir:RateFlow" rateParameter="//@parameters.2" target="//@compartments.3"/>
</compartments>

backward_compatibility.description: TRM features are fully optional - classical traffic models work unchanged
backward_compatibility.detection: Equation generator automatically detects TRM types

trm_applications: Highway traffic simulation with kinetic interpretation
Stability analysis using reaction network theory

references: Pereira, F. L., Figueiredo, J., & Ramos, C. C. (2024). The Traffic Reaction Model: A kinetic compartmental approach to road traffic modeling. Transportation Research Part B, 179, 102871.
Coogan, S., & Arcak, M. (2015). A Compartmental Model for Traffic Networks and its Dynamical Behavior. IEEE Trans. Automatic Control, 60(10), 2698-2703.
Daganzo, C. F. (1995). The Cell Transmission Model, Part II: Network Traffic. Transportation Research Part B, 29(2), 79-93.

parameter_system.description: NEW in Version 2.0: Comprehensive parameter system for symbolic/parametric modeling
features: Three parameter types: CONSTANT, VARIABLE, EXPRESSION
Parameter references in RateFlow, ContactFlow, BirthSource, DeathSink, StratumSpecificRate
Unicode support for Greek symbols and mathematical notation
Separation of model structure from parameter values
Automatic equation generation with symbolic output
benefits: Reusability: Change parameters without modifying model structure
Documentation: Parameters carry descriptions and units
Professional output: Equations match published papers (β₁, μₕ instead of 0.9969, 0.001384)
Environmental dependencies: Temperature, rainfall, intervention levels
Backward compatibility: Existing numeric models continue working

stratification_system.description: Stratification system using Groups and Products
stratification_system.Groups: Define demographic or risk categories (e.g., age groups, gender, risk levels)
stratification_system.Products: Combine multiple groups for complex stratification
stratification_system.compartment_stratification: Compartments can reference a Product to be automatically stratified

flow_enhancements.abstract_flows: Flow is now abstract with RateFlow and ContactFlow as concrete implementations
flow_enhancements.stratum_specific_rates: Both RateFlow and ContactFlow support different rates for different strata (numeric or parametric)
flow_enhancements.contact_modeling: ContactFlow enables sophisticated transmission modeling with contact compartments
flow_enhancements.parameter_references: All flows can reference parameters instead of using numeric attributes

population_dynamics.BirthSource: Models population inflow (births, immigration, recruitment). Supports numeric rates and parameter references.
population_dynamics.DeathSink: Models population outflow (deaths, emigration). Supports numeric rates and parameter references.
population_dynamics.global_rates: SEIRModel can specify totalPopulation, globalBirthRate, globalDeathRate

diagram_support.description: Sirius diagrams intelligently display parameter names or numeric values
diagram_support.implementation: AQL expressions check for parameter references using ->notEmpty(), displaying parameter names when available or numeric values otherwise
diagram_support.greek_symbols: Full Unicode support in diagram labels for professional mathematical notation

equation_generation.description: SEIREquationGenerator produces symbolic equations for parametric models
features: Parameter names in equations (γₕ, ρₕ, β₁) instead of numbers (0.120342, 0.001995, 0.9969)
EXPRESSION parameters expanded in equations
Backward compatible with numeric models
Output matches mathematical notation in published papers

numeric_modeling.description: Traditional approach using hardcoded numeric values
limitations: Equations show numbers instead of symbolic names
Hard to track which number represents which parameter
Changing a parameter value requires finding all uses
Doesn't match mathematical notation in papers

parametric_modeling.description: NEW approach using named parameters with references
when_to_use: Published models needing to match paper equations
parametric_modeling.example_snippet:
<parameters name="γₕ" expression="0.120342" description="Recovery rate Ih to Rh" unit="1/time"/>
<outgoingFlows xsi:type="seir:RateFlow" rateParameter="//@parameters.9" target="//@compartments.3"/>
benefits: Equations show symbolic names (γₕ, μₕ, β₁)
Parameters documented with descriptions and units
Easy to change parameter values in one place
Supports Greek symbols and professional notation
Enables sensitivity analysis and parameter sweeps

mixed_modeling.description: Combination of numeric and parametric approaches in the same model
mixed_modeling.when_to_use: Transitioning from numeric to parametric, or when only some parameters need symbolic representation
mixed_modeling.priority: Parameter references take precedence over numeric attributes when both are present

model_type_selection.disease_models: Use standard compartments with rate-based and contact-based flows. Do not add supplyFunction or set junctionRule.
model_type_selection.traffic_models: Use compartments with supplyFunction element and junctionRule="PPFIFO". Use parameters for split ratios (β) and supply/demand function parameters.
model_type_selection.mixed_models: Not recommended - keep disease and traffic models separate for clarity

flow_network_design: Define source nodes with isSourceNode=true and maxDemand parameter
Define constrained nodes with isSourceNode=false and maxDensity, criticalDensity, maxThroughput parameters
Use RateFlow with routing coefficient parameters (e.g., β_{lk} for split ratios in traffic) for routing
Use BirthSource for source node external input/demand (e.g., d_l in traffic)
Set junctionRule="PPFIFO" for all flow network compartments
Use Parameters for all network-specific values (allows easy modification and sensitivity analysis)
parameter_naming: Disease models: Use Greek symbols (β for transmission, μ for mortality, γ for recovery, ρ for progression)
Traffic models: Use standard notation (ρ for density, Φ for flow, β for split ratio)
Use subscripts to distinguish entities (μₕ for human, μᵥ for vector, β_{12} for split ratio link 1→2)
Use function notation for dependencies: a(T) for temperature-dependent, θᵥ(T,R) for temperature and rainfall
model_structure: Use BirthSource for all population inflows (not flows from nowhere)
Use DeathSink for all population outflows (not flows to nowhere)
Use RateFlow for progression, recovery, immunity loss
Use ContactFlow for transmission and infection
parametric_vs_numeric: For new models: Use parametric approach for better maintainability
For existing models: Can keep numeric or migrate to parametric
When using parametric: Set numeric attributes to 0.0
When unsure: Start parametric, easier to maintain long-term
